item.title: I really like the idea of MAML as a tool to learn efficiently-learning neural networks. In cognitive science/evolution, there's the related Baldwin effect, "an organism's ability to learn new behaviours (e.g. to acclimatise to a new stressor) will affect its reproduction" 2/

item.title: Perhaps brains and language co-evolved to facilitate the process of learning languages. This sounds tautological but it's not: to put it into machine learning terms, it's saying evolution helped learned the hyperparameters (genes) 3/

item.title: I think that's cool because it addresses a fundamental issue in neuroAI: why are humans so sample-efficient and ANNs aren't. And it offers one small chunk of an answer, and opens a whole new area of inquiry. See also https://t.co/3u7c5ovt2v 5/

item.title: Life has been evolving for over 3 billion years, and brains appeared only 0.5 billion years ago. If life were a TV series, the brain would be a new character that's introduced in season 7 and quickly dominates the show to the dismay of older fans.
